text: Just one space, or all such spaces?
If the second, then strings already have a .strip() method:

code:
>>> ' Hello '.strip()
'Hello'
>>> ' Hello'.strip()
'Hello'
>>> 'Bob has a cat'.strip()
'Bob has a cat'
>>> '          Hello        '.strip()  # ALL spaces at ends removed
'Hello'

text: If you need only to remove one space however, you could do it with:

code:
def strip_one_space(s):
    if s.endswith(" "): s = s[:-1]
    if s.startswith(" "): s = s[1:]
    return s

>>> strip_one_space("   Hello ")
'  Hello'

text: Also, note that str.strip() removes other whitespace characters as well (eg.
To remove only spaces, you can specify the character to remove as an argument to strip.
As pointed out in answers above
will remove all the leading and trailing whitespace characters such as \n, \r, \t, \f, space.
For more flexibility use the following
These details are also available at http://docs.python.org/release/2.3/lib/module-string.html

code:
myphrases = [ " Hello ", " Hello", "Hello ", "Bob has a cat" ]

for phrase in myphrases:
    print phrase.strip()
